column1: On 7 June 2016, Ipswich Town defeated AZ Alkmaar 3-0 in the first leg of the cup final, resulting in a 4-2 aggregate win and lifting the trophy. Butcher was part of the winning team and later participated in a charity cycling event, raising funds for Prostate Cancer UK and the Ipswich Town Academy.

Storms Desmond, Eva, Frank, and Gertrude caused significant flooding in Hawick, Jedburgh, Newcastleton, and Peebles. The full repair costs are yet to be determined, but the council will receive Bellwin Scheme support. They must contribute 0.2% of their net revenue budget (£508,000) and complete 240 repair projects (114 classified as major). Additional works may be needed for bridges inspected underwater.

Thomas Cook Airlines will launch a weekly Glasgow-Las Vegas flight from May to October 2015, following successful one-off flights in recent years. The airline also plans to increase its Tunisian flights to three times weekly in 2015.

England, Wales, and Northern Ireland are in pot one while the Republic of Ireland could join them from the play-offs. Potential groups include England, Italy, the Czech Republic, and either Wales or Northern Ireland. Seeding is based on UEFA national team coefficient rankings. Top seeds for the finals include Spain, France, Germany, Portugal, and Belgium. Bosnia and Herzegovina, Ukraine, Sweden, and Hungary are seeds in the play-off draw. The Republic of Ireland, Denmark, Norway, and Slovenia could face off in the play-off matches. The finals draw is on 12 December.

Damon Smith denied making an explosive device intending to endanger life, but admitted to a bomb hoax. The Improvised Explosive Device contained ball bearings as shrapnel, and was meant to look like a real bomb to stop the train and get news coverage. Smith has Asperger's syndrome and is interested in weapons, though he does not hold extreme views.

Mansfield District Council debated the £250m Lindhurst scheme, facing 140 objections, including concerns from wildlife trusts and walkers. The largest development in the council's history, it includes 1,700 homes, a primary school, cemetery, community centre, and park. The planning committee voted five in favour, five against, with the chairman casting the deciding vote. Protesters shouted "shame" after the decision was made.
UN finds Europe throws away most fish globally, with almost 25% of catches discarded as unsought.

In 2011, HP purchased Palm for $1.2bn and acquired the WebOS operating system. Despite not recovering much of the purchase price, LG acquired WebOS to power its next-generation smart TV technology. WebOS was originally designed for smartphones and tablets, but competition from Apple, Android, and Blackberry has reduced Palm's influence. The acquisition may help WebOS return to its smartphone roots, and LG aims to differentiate through software-based innovation in user experience.

In a pre-season friendly, Ipswich Town and the University of Maryland men's soccer teams played to a 1-1 draw. Ipswich's Andre Dozzell opened the scoring before Joe Pigott equalized in the 89th minute. Manager Mick McCarthy was furious with his team's late goal concession and cited previous late defeats as the reason for his anger.

Tests conducted at the British Library revealed that Jane Austen's eyesight significantly deteriorated due to possible arsenic poisoning from medications she may have taken for rheumatism. This contributed to her early death at age 41, causing much speculation about the cause of her passing. The three pairs of glasses found in her writing desk show an increase in lens strength over time, making it increasingly difficult for her to read or write.

Archbishop Justin Welby announced plans to fix Easter Sunday dates after meeting with Anglican Primates. The 1928 Act of Parliament has never been activated, leaving Easter celebration based on the moon's cycle. Welby hopes to implement change within 5-10 years, with discussions involving Pope Francis, Coptic leader Pope Tawadros, and Orthodox Patriarch Bartholomew.

A monthly survey of businesses shows a modest deterioration in April, with output and new orders declining after growth in March. Ulster Bank's chief economist, Richard Ramsey, says Northern Ireland's private sector activity is compared to growth in other UK regions. Manufacturing is strong, while retail sales and construction show declines. Despite weak data, hiring continues. Looking forward, fiscal plans and economic policies will affect the economy.

Penarth's high street shop has become a target for opposition since opening in November. Anti-UKIP protesters have invited anarchists to throw eggs at posters of leader Nigel Farage and candidates John Rees-Evans. However, UKIP claims no eggs have been thrown since the posters were put up.

On the opening night of "One Man, Two Guvnors" at Windsor's Theatre Royal, a flood forced audience members to be evacuated. The theatre director announced that the auditorium had been dried out and the show would resume on Wednesday. This incident occurred during a six-week festival celebrating 201 years of theatre in the Berkshire town.

Fiji gained independence from Britain in 1970. Political instability stems from rivalry between indigenous Fijians and ethnic Indians. In 2014, Frank Bainimarama became PM following a military coup. Population 876,000; area 18,376 sq km; major languages English, Fijian, Hindi; major religions Christianity, Hinduism, Islam; life expectancy 67 yrs (men), 72 yrs (women); currency Fijian dollar; president Jioji Konousi Konrote; prime minister Josaia Voreqe "Frank" Bainimarama. Media restrictions have led to self-censorship. Key dates include 1643 (Dutch explorer Abel Tasman visits), 1970 (independence), 1987 (first coup), 1999 (Mahendra Chaudhry elected PM), 2012 (Media Decree introduced), and 2014 (Bainimarama becomes PM).

A 17-year-old student's comment about political science being about cooking sparked controversy in India after a video of her interview went viral. This led to a markedly lower pass rate in exams, prompting the state government to announce tougher measures like fines and jail terms to curb cheating. However, the success of these measures was called into question when two top students, including Ruby Rai, were found to have questionable results. As a result, the two students and 12 others will have to appear for a written test and interview before a panel of subject experts on 3 June to verify their results.

About 30 people have been living in a tent camp outside Manchester Central Library since 15 April. After an appeal was lost, campaigners were issued a warrant to close the camp. They have now set up a new settlement half a mile away in St Anne's Square. Police and bailiffs broke up the St Peter's Square camp at 08:00 BST. The council said some demonstrators had behaved inappropriately in a public area. The camp has cost the council and police over Â£88,000 in additional costs.

Two pieces of debris from MH370, which disappeared in 2014 with 239 people on board, were found separately and flown to Australia for analysis. Darren Chester said the findings were consistent with drift modelling, suggesting the debris came from the missing plane. The search for the plane continues in the southern Indian Ocean.

RMT union plans further strike action against ScotRail over driver-only trains; Labour urges minister to intervene. Talks through Acas fail; RMT opposes door control change. ScotRail says 59% of customers already travel on driver-operated trains; 80% of services expected to run normally this weekend. Passengers advised to check ScotRail strike info web page before travelling.

In the NBA playoffs, the Cavaliers trail 2-1 after defeating the Warriors 112-107. Kyrie Irving scored 30 points while Steph Curry had 19. Warriors coach Steve Kerr blamed his team's lack of preparation, while LeBron James credited his teammates for encouraging him to be aggressive. Game 4 is on Friday in Cleveland.

Goulding's Burn tops the charts, selling 117,000 copies, beating Avicii's Wake Me Up by 40,000. Lady Gaga's Applause enters at five, while Miley Cyrus's We Can't Stop falls to three. Goulding's previous high was two with Your Song (2010). Burn is on Halcyon (deluxe), climbing to 19 in the album chart. Goulding tells the chart compiler it means the world to be number one. Arctic Monkeys' Why'd You Call Me enters at eight, while The Wanted's We Own the Night reaches 10. Ray Foxx's Boom Boom enters at 12. Richard and Adam Johnson hold on to the top spot for a third week with Britain's Got Talent debut album, The Impossible Dream.

Scotland's Highland Council avoided £1.3m in planned cuts through savings such as £500k from changes in sickness absence policy and £500k in school energy incentives. A cut pay proposal for senior councillors by the Liberal Democrats was defeated. The ruling group proposed cuts in funding for deprived areas, street cleansing, homeless support, women's aid groups, and the Blas Music Festival. The savings were necessary due to the council tax freeze. Highland Council faced unprecedented challenges in balancing its budget.

Reverend Barry Trayhorn, a Pentecostal Christian minister, was unfairly dismissed from his job at HMP Littlehey in Cambridgeshire after reading verses from the Bible during a service in 2014. His case against the secretary of state for justice continues.

Inspector John Vine says Home Office must improve handling of 'overstayers', as foreign nationals refused leave to stay in UK. Immigration Minister James Brokenshire acknowledges room for improvement. Report shows 'overstayer' numbers remain stable; Capita contracts criticised for inaccuracies.

Dolgellau's My Dentist practice will close on 31 March due to lack of permanent dentists. Deputy mayor Delwyn Evans blames lack of dentists in rural areas. Clinical director Steve Williams says recruitment efforts failed for two years. Betsi Cadwaladr Health Board intends to re-commission dental services in the area. Welsh Government spokesman says funding remains with health board to re-commission services.

A massive search for missing climber Liam Day, 26, was launched by police and coastguard crews before being suspended. His partner, Emily Brown, posted on Facebook suggesting he might not be found. Mr Day is thought to have been climbing alone near Durlston Country Park when he disappeared. Police are appealing for witnesses who saw a climber in the area.

In the All-Ireland semi-final, manager McGuinness must develop a strategy to counter the attacking style of the defending champions. Trusting his players, he focuses on getting things right before the game. Despite being ranked as underdogs, McGuinness is unperturbed, as they were also underdogs in 2012. The focus is on football and preparing for the game.

In 2015, High Fliers Market Research reported 1,000 graduates rejected job offers at the last minute, forcing employers to search for replacements. Around 20,000 students were recruited mainly during their final year. Students can adjust their plans if better opportunities arise. Top employers compete for top candidates, while the number of graduates hired rose 3.3% in 2015, with average salaries staying at around Â£30,000.

A man suffered head and leg injuries after falling onto the tracks at a London train station shortly after England's World Cup win. The man was not critically injured and the station was evacuated for treatment. British Transport Police are investigating the incident.

Malta, located south of Sicily between Europe and North Africa, has a long history of colonial control by various nations such as Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, Arabs, and France, and Britain. The Maltese people were awarded the George Cross for their bravery during WWII, and independence was achieved in 1964. Malta's strategic location made it an important trading post, and today it is a leading center for container and freight transhipment. Tourism is the main source of income, and the population is approximately 419,000.

34-year-old actor plays grieving investment banker in Jean-Marc Vallee's tragicomedy Demolition, making its world premiere at TIFF. Over 11 days, almost 400 films screen including Michael Moore's satirical US military film Where to Invade Next. Past TIFF winners like 12 Years a Slave and The King's Speech went on to win Oscars.

A boy battling a brain condition and injured in a petrol bomb attack in Newtownabbey dominates the Belfast Telegraph's front page. His mother, Danielle Thompson, explains how fire from the attack caused scars from one of his three life-saving operations to erupt in blisters. The Irish News reports that five Orange Halls have been awarded grants under a controversial Stormont scheme, while a County Tyrone boy fights life-threatening epilepsy in the US using cannabis oil. The News Letter reports that a prosecution decision on a man linked to the Kingsmills massacre is set to be announced within two weeks.

A survey of 1,000 adults found that one-third would ignore the safe level on their music players, increasing the risk of tinnitus. Action on Hearing Loss warned that one in 10 people in the UK suffers from tinnitus daily, affecting concentration and sleep. The group created an audio representation of tinnitus to raise awareness and urged people to use ear defenders at concerts and turn down the volume on personal devices. DJ Paul Oakenfold supported the campaign, urging safe music consumption and proper ear protection.

In the Hopman Cup, France defeated the United States in a deciding doubles match to take the lead in the mixed team event. Previously, France won the tournament in 2014 while Great Britain failed to advance past the group stage this year.

Australia-born England coach Steve Jones says he feels the long-standing rivalry between England and Ireland as they prepare to face each other at Twickenham on Saturday. Jones, who previously coached Australia, revealed that he sees Leicester centre Manu Tuilagi as a future 12 shirt for England. England are tied with France at the top of the Six Nations table.

In the six months to September, Scottish paramedics treated around 12,000 people for alcohol-related illnesses. The Scottish Conservatives obtained the figures through freedom of information laws. Alcohol significantly impacted the Scottish Ambulance Service's operations, as shown by a recent survey showing it was a factor in more than half of all weekend call-outs. NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde had the highest number of alcohol-related 999 call-outs, followed by NHS Lothian and NHS Lanarkshire. Tory health spokesman Jackson Carlaw called for more action to discourage reckless drinking and improve paramedic safety. Public Health Minister Maureen Watt said Scotland was leading the way in tackling alcohol misuse.

Economic inactivity in Northern Ireland stands at 27%, lower than the UK average of 22%. The "Enabling Success" strategy aims to raise employment levels through 11 projects targeting those with work-limiting health conditions, lone parents, and people with caring commitments. By 2030, the strategy hopes to raise employment levels above the UK average.

Reality TV star and billionaire Donald Trump sparked controversy by questioning the hero status of former prisoner of war and Senator John McCain. He later clarified his remarks without apologising, adding that he disagreed with McCain's Senate performance. Trump's comments drew strong criticism from fellow Republicans, including rival candidate Rick Perry, who called them a "new low" in US politics.

Canadian author Ray Kinsella died at age 76, with his agent confirming his death was doctor-assisted and legal in Canada since this year. He published over 30 works in poetry, fiction, and non-fiction, winning the Order of Canada. Kinsella is best known for his baseball-themed fantasy novel Shoeless Joe, which was adapted into the 1989 film Field of Dreams. After a head injury, Kinsella lost interest in fiction, but resumed writing; his final work, Russian Dolls, is scheduled for release next year.

Máiría Cahill, a Labour Party candidate, won a by-election to fill a vacant seat in parliament. She defeated three other candidates with 122 votes out of 188 valid votes. Cahill, whose family has ties to the Irish republican movement, has spoken publicly about being raped by an IRA member when she was 16. This year, Northern Ireland's Public Prosecution Service apologised to Cahill for delays in her case. After her election, Cahill pledged to advocate for sexual abuse victims and explore ways to engage young jobseekers.

Separate calls to ChildLine from boys in Cardiff and Prestatyn revealed their concerns about the impact of pornography. The charity launched a campaign to address the "shocking" number of 12-13 year-olds worried about their alleged addiction to porn. One child felt pornography made him feel "perverted". A UK-wide poll found that one in five children had seen pornographic images that shocked or upset them. Des Mannion, NSPCC national head of service for Wales, called for society to talk about the issue to help the thousands of young people affected.

Mariner Street car park will be transformed into a 725-bedroom student block with amenities including a nightclub, gym, offices, bars, restaurants, and shops. The 22-storey tower will be the second tallest building in Swansea, after Meridian Quay. Construction is expected to begin this year and be completed by 2018. The project will help meet the growing demand for student housing in Swansea as the city's universities expand. Swansea council leader Rob Stewart believes the development will be a major step forward for the city's regeneration.

Cyclone Debbie's remnants caused floods in Queensland and NSW, with rivers breaking their banks and roads washed away. Towns such as Billinudgel saw residents use surfboards to navigate flooded streets. Brisbane was affected, and evacuation orders were issued for Beaudesert. South Murwillumbah was hard hit, and insurers are yet to estimate the damage bill. Authorities said tens of thousands lost power, and a bull shark was found in the floods. The storm system has since moved out to sea.

An iPad software glitch caused issues with flight plans for American Airlines pilots, leading to some flights being grounded. The airline implemented electronic flight bags in 2013 to save fuel costs and reduce flight preparation time. Competitors like United Airlines, Delta, British Airways, and Ryanair are also transitioning to similar systems.

A court in Mumbai convicted 35-year-old Girish Pote for the 2013 murder of his wife Madhuvanti Pathak, whose body was chopped into pieces. The crime came to light after Pote confessed to relatives, who informed the police. A life term in India usually lasts 14 years, but Judge Mridula Bhatia ruled that Pote would remain in prison for the rest of his life due to the "gruesome" nature of the crime. Pathak held a French passport. The couple had a two-year-old son when the crime occurred. Police said Pote had been fighting with his wife over money and her desire to return to France.

Bradford Council plans a one-way gyratory system on East Parade, Hanover Street, and Cavendish Street to address traffic congestion. Deputy leader Val Salter emphasizes urgency for action. Public display of plans is scheduled for 11 and 13 June at the Airedale shopping center.

23-year-old Thorpe has made 7 appearances for Bradford this season, last featuring in a 5-2 loss to Ipswich on 7 November. He could make his debut against Millwall on Saturday as Bradford battle for a play-off spot in League One.

A radio presenter tricked Spanish PM Rajoy into meeting a fake Puigdemont, mimicking a dispute between them over Catalonia's future. Rajoy, who won elections but lacked a majority, was angered but took it lightly. He's not the first leader to fall for a prank; Blair & Castro also got fooled.

Lib Dem Baroness Hamwee questioned whether the £1 pay rate for non-criminal detainees was something society could be proud of. Baroness Williams of Trafford explained that inmate work was voluntary, helping meet recreational and intellectual needs, not aimed at saving money. Labour's Lord Rosser claimed hundreds of detainees had been paid £45,438 for 44,832 hours work, with potential savings of £300,000 per month. Baroness Williams insisted the work benefited detainees, but Lady Boothroyd pressed for clarification on who reaped the financial benefit.

This year's Borders Book Festival will announce the winner of the Â£25,000 Walter Scott Prize, which recognises outstanding historical fiction. Seven authors, including Jo Baker, Sebastian Barry, and Rose Tremain, are in the running. Judges praised the variety and quality of the longlisted novels, which offer readers joy in discovering unique subjects and times. The finalists will compete for the award at the festival on 17 June.

In the second innings of the first Test between Bangladesh and England, Bangladesh needed 33 runs to win their first Test match. England was bowled out for 240, while Bangladesh scored 253-8. The match was halted due to bad light, with England deciding to bowl in the second innings.

Members of UCU Scotland voted for strike action over job security at the university's medical school. The university expressed disappointment with the decision. UCU raised concerns about potential discrimination against four Asian ethnic staff members. The university stated that no compulsory redundancies would be needed due to restructuring and alternative employment being offered to the affected staff.

In October 2012, a tragic fire killed five people in Prestatyn, Denbighshire. The owner, Jay Brenton Liptrot, 43, did not enter a plea when he appeared in court on Friday. Melanie Smith, who started the fire in a row over a shared hallway, was jailed for at least 30 years for five counts of murder. Mr Liptrot will appear at Mold Crown Court in May.

Aberdeen Sea Cadets base at Pocra Quay witnessed an unfortunate incident, deemed "disgraceful" by Police Scotland. A 34-year-old man is expected to appear in court, though he has been released from custody pending further investigation.

A report titled "Read On. Get On." highlights the importance of early reading for children's future success. It reveals that children who fall behind in reading are less likely to obtain good qualifications or pursue further education. To address this issue, a coalition including Save the Children and the Scottish Book Trust aims to get all 11-year-olds reading well within a generation. They advocate daily reading sessions for young children and encourage parents to engage in these activities. However, low-income families face challenges due to lack of access to children's books and involvement from fathers in reading activities. The coalition aims to address these issues and create a fairer environment for learning to read.

In 2016, 30-year-old hockey player Martinelli joined the Giants, committing to the franchise alongside Mark Garside, who will spend an eighth consecutive year with the club. Both players were part of past Giants squads that won league championships. Martinelli is described as a great guy in the locker room, and Head Coach Adam Keefe is excited about Garside's extended stay.

16-year-old Rasmus Barlow disappeared on Monday, triggering a massive police search. His death is not suspected, and the coroner's office will investigate. Family liaison officers are supporting the teen's family.

A 55-year-old teacher, Regina Hungerford, was found guilty of making physical contact with a 17-year-old student during an altercation in her classroom. The Education Workforce Council ruled that her actions were unacceptable and will decide whether to strike her off the register at a later date. Despite her denial, the panel found that her conduct fell short of the standard expected of a registered teacher.

On Star Wars Day (May 4), big brands use hashtags like #MayThe4thBeWithYou to promote products and exhibits. Mark Hamill, Darth Vader, and celebrities join in the fun. Heathrow Airport, The British Museum, and charities also participate. Everyone celebrates Star Wars in their own way.

Retired generals and admirals endorse Trump, saying he has the right temperament to be president. Trump dismisses allegations of improper donations to Florida officials. Clinton releases campaign ad featuring veterans criticizing Trump.
Young defender joins Colchester on one-year deal after making limited appearances for Tykes.

In 2017, Phillip Pullman announced his new trilogy, The Book of Dust, with the first novel due for release in October. Pullman's bestselling His Dark Materials series began with Northern Lights (1995) and has sold over 17.5 million copies in 40 languages. The new series will follow Lyra Belacqua from infancy to her 20s.

A Red Cross pool safety poster sparked outrage for depicting black children as "not cool" while white children were considered "cool". The poster led to an apology from the Red Cross, which pledged to remove the image and stop printing it.

Winkelman confirmed that Karl Robinson, English football's third-longest serving manager, will remain in place for the upcoming season. He added that he trusts Robinson's leadership and is excited about the challenges ahead as a "bigger club" in League One.

Scottish actors James Cosmo (Braveheart) and Karen Gillan (Dr Who), now directors, join EIFF honorary patrons as Mark Adams, artistic director, praises their achievements. Both feel honoured and privileged for the opportunity. Gillan, who moved to Edinburgh at 16 for acting studies, expresses excitement about returning to celebrate Scottish and international filmmaking.

Spurs player Danny Rose says the team needs to sign well-known players; manager Mauricio Pochettino supports Rose's future at the club. Rose apologises for his comments. Spurs have not signed any players yet & Kyle Walker was sold to Man City. Kieran Trippier's ankle injury not as severe as first feared.

International Ski Federation (FIS) banned Thai skier Mae and five officials for manipulating results to ensure her Sochi Olympics qualification. The Court of Arbitration for Sport will now consider her appeal. Born in Singapore, Vanessa Vanakorn competed for Britain in Sochi under her father's surname. She finished 67th in the Giant Slalom.

In the seventh minute, Rhys Browne scored for Macclesfield Town, breaking the deadlock. Both sides created chances in an open first half, but the score remained 1-0 at the break. In the second half, Macclesfield had a goal disallowed, and Eastleigh came close to equalising before Macclesfield won 1-0.

Warner Bros. TV is yet to agree on salaries with the main cast of The Big Bang Theory, leading to possible production delays. If no new deals are reached in the next two weeks, the popular CBS sitcom could be impacted. However, according to The Hollywood Reporter, the cast is still expected to return to work. The show, which revolves around highly skilled science geeks, has been extended for three more series, airing until at least 2017. Parsons, Galecki, and Cuoco are seeking up to $1 million per episode, making them the highest-paid actors on US television.

A fatal car crash occurred between Newlyns and Lodge Farms in North Warnborough, resulting in the death of Alexander Worth. Matthew Cobden, of Walton-on-Thames, was arrested and appeared at Basingstoke Magistrates' Court. Cobden sustained serious injuries in the crash but no other vehicles were involved. The judge expressed sympathy to Alexander's family and granted Cobden unconditional bail with the case referred to Winchester Crown Court on 26 July.

Refugees gathered on Queen Street calling for concrete action, welcoming the UK's plan to resettle 20,000 Syrians. Demonstrations took place in Swansea and Caernarfon, while Wales' First Minister Carwyn Jones will host a summit on the refugee crisis next week. Local authorities are willing to assist but need financial help.

Jhon Jairo Velasquez, known as Popeye, was a notorious Colombian hitman for drug baron Pablo Escobar. He confessed to killing 300 people and claimed responsibility for up to 3,000 killings between the 1980s and 1990s. However, he also provided evidence against an ex-justice minister, leading to his conviction for ordering the killing of a rival candidate. After serving two decades in prison, Velasquez was released on probation in 2021, sparking controversy among Colombians divided over whether he had paid for his crimes or deserved a second chance.

Kurt Gidley, a 34-year-old rugby league player, wore a camera during a match on Thursday, becoming the first player to do so. However, the camera was removed due to technical issues, and the player was able to focus on his game. Coach Tony Smith stated that while the camera may have affected Gidley's performance, it was done for the right reasons and they would like to review the footage. Sky Sports, the broadcasters of Super League, plan to continue the experiment.

Police investigated a sexual assault at a care home in Campbeltown. The suspect is an 82-year-old man; the victim is a 76-year-old woman. The Procurator Fiscal has received a report on the matter. The Care Inspectorate is monitoring the situation closely and has set up a helpline for people with concerns.

Des McDaid, who revealed his identity, testified about sexual abuse in various institutions during the Historical Institutional Abuse Inquiry. He was sent to Australia at age eight and suffered abuse by Christian Brothers and a lay teacher. Mr. McDaid hopes people remember his helplessness. He is in contact with his mother and plans to visit next month. The inquiry heard about 131 child migrants from NI, including 50 whose experiences will be examined.

In an exciting match, world number 45 lost to reigning US Open champion Wawrinka in the Australian Open quarterfinals. Canadian Raonic defeated Nadal while British player Bedene was knocked out in India. Semi-finals will feature Wawrinka vs. Nishikori and Raonic vs. Dimitrov.

Irish rock band U2's 50-year-old musician required treatment in a Munich neurosurgery clinic, postponing their upcoming US tour and possibly their Glastonbury appearance. Manager Paul McGuinness plans to reinstate tour dates as soon as possible, causing disruption to the band's 400-strong crew. Fans should monitor the U2 website for updates.

A train derailed between Abergavenny and Raglan, injuring 3 people including passengers and pilot. Road closed, with 2 South Wales fire engines on scene. Fuel leak contained; estimated 120 litres on board.

Angela Scott, 42, will join Aberdeen City Council as its new chief executive in July, replacing Valerie Watts. Mrs Scott is currently the council's director of corporate governance. The council leader, Barney Crockett, praised her financial expertise, drive, and leadership skills. Mrs Scott said she was proud to accept the job and looked forward to working with key partners to deliver the city's priorities. Her annual salary is Â£144,685.

United defender Matteo Darmian suffered a dislocated shoulder, ruling him out for several weeks. This leaves Luke Shaw, Marcos Rojo, Ashley Young, Antonio Valencia, Phil Jones, and Guillermo Varela injured, leaving Cameron Borthwick-Jackson and Donald Love as the only fit full-backs.

Kenneth Harper, 33, was convicted of sex crimes, assault, and reckless behaviour, but his rape convictions were quashed due to defense arguments about mutual corroboration. He was sentenced to three years for the remaining offenses. Solicitor John Keenan challenged the rape convictions, arguing that the two alleged offenses were separated by an eight-year time gap and occurred in different circumstances with no "extraordinary features" linking them. The Crown claimed compelling similarities involving vulnerable women significantly younger than Harper, but Lord Brodie ruled there was no special feature to link the incidents.

Actor Tom Broadbent is thrilled to portray Tommy Butler, an "old-school" detective, in the drama The Great Train Robbery: A Copper's Tale. Following the perspective of the perpetrators in A Robber's Tale, the new series will air later this year. Chris Chibnall, executive producer and writer, described Broadbent as a "dream piece of casting".

A Lithuanian schoolgirl was brutally attacked in a brawl in Peterborough's Central Park. Her mother shared a video of the fight on Facebook, which has been viewed over 680,000 times. Police are investigating the incident, while the victim claims the attackers thought she had been "cheeky" to some of them at school.

The Maccabees achieve their first number one album with "Marks To Prove It", beating Lianne La Havas' "Blood" by 1,300 copies. Cilla Black's posthumous entry into the charts sees her "Very Best of Cilla Black" reach #14 and her former #1 single "Anyone Who Had A Heart" enter at #41 after 51 years. One Direction releases "Drag Me Down" as a foursome after Zayn Malik's departure, while Calvin Harris & Disciples' "How Deep Is Your Love" climbs to #2, pushing Little Mix's "Black Magic" to #3. The top five is completed by Lost Frequencies' "Are You With Me" and Years & Years' "Shine". The Maccabees narrowly beat Lianne La Havas for their first number one album.

One Direction continues as a four-piece after Zayn Malik's departure due to stress and rumours of a breakup. Liam Payne thanked fans for supporting the band during their On the Road Again tour. They will play concerts in Europe, starting with a show in Cardiff on 5 June.
Police Scotland investigating leak of witnesses' names, alleged gun hit details on social media; inquiries ongoing.

Steven Flynn broke into McDiarmid Park stadium with a crowbar to pay off drug debts. Police arrived but mistakenly believed the window was accidentally left open. A cleaner discovered the break-in and alerted authorities, leading to Flynn's arrest. He was sentenced to 16 months in prison.

On Monday, Nigel Farage visited Sleaford, standing in front of a UKIP poster with an incorrect spelling of the constituency name, North Hykenham. The by-election takes place on Thursday, with candidates from various parties vying for the vacant seat. The constituency is vacant following the resignation of Conservative MP Stephen Phillips, who had held the seat since 2010.

In the first minute, Blair Henderson scored for the hosts after receiving a cross from Michael McKenna. Stirling had a chance but Moses Olanrewaju's shot was saved. Brian Martin was sent off after handling the ball in the penalty area, and despite Sean Dickson missing the penalty, Stirling couldn't equalize.

Fiona Barnes, who faked terminal cancer, was sentenced to 15 months in jail for theft from Preston's Space Centre and perverting the course of justice. The 55-year-old was ordered to repay £1 despite the centre saying the ruling was "outrageous" and a "complete insult". The Space Centre, the UK's largest multi-sensory environment supporting children with physical, learning, or emotional difficulties, was saved by a charitable company based in Manchester.

Experienced defender Adam El-Abd, 31, has joined Shrewsbury Town from Bristol City after starting his career at Brighton, where he made over 300 appearances in 11 years. He had loan spells with Bury, Swindon, and Gillingham before moving to Ashton Gate in 2014. El-Abd joins fellow defender Joe Riley in Micky Mellon's squad as the manager continues to rebuild ahead of the new League One season.

England rugby coach Eddie Jones believes his team needs to develop more leaders to win the 2019 World Cup. He attributes this to modern society's shift towards sheltered environments like academies. Jones aims to develop more leaders within the team, with Dylan Hartley set to captain the Six Nations side and Owen Farrell a potential replacement should he be unavailable.

Somerset County Championship team signs Australian batsman Chris Rogers, 38, who will bat at number three for the summer. Maynard is delighted with the signing, seeing it as a "top" and "marquee" player. Rogers' experience will help support the opening duo of Marcus Trescothick and Tom Abell, 21, and Maynard hopes it will also benefit the younger members of the squad.

A Range Rover crashed into a house on Hearthcote Road in Swadlincote, Derbyshire, around 2 AM BST, causing structural damage and forcing two residents to evacuate. No serious injuries were reported, and the road was closed for approximately an hour. Police are investigating and seeking witnesses.

Demolition of the Kingsway building began in 2015 but asbestos issues delayed progress. The council aims to transform the area into a business district. Internal works are complete; exterior demolition is ongoing and scheduled for completion by spring.
Rovers led 2-1 but referee Harrington ruled out Hanley's goal. Bowyer called for goal-line tech similar to Premier League in Championship. Fulham's Kit Symons also backed introduction.

19-year-old Polish midfielder Kapustka joins Leicester City for £7.5m, signing a five-year deal. He impressed at Euro 2016 and now joins the club ahead of a friendly against Barcelona. This is Claudio Ranieri's fifth summer signing after Zieler, Hernandez, Mendy, and Musa.

The Burrell Collection will close for redevelopment in 2020, with planned improvements including a new roof, energy efficiency measures, and two additional exhibition floors. During the closure, select pieces from the collection will be displayed at Kelvingrove Museum and Art Gallery.

Hundreds of chicken farmers receive heating subsidies through a scheme that helps them switch from LPG to wood chip boilers. Finance Minister Máirtín Ó Muilleoir raises fresh concerns over the operation of the scheme, while Moy Park, a poultry processing company, claims to have extensive experience in benchmarked energy use and advocates responsible heat use. The minister criticizes proposed cost control measures as a "sticking plaster" and insists on a permanent solution to the RHI scandal.
Man found dead in field near Belsyde Avenue; police investigating identity & cause of death.

On 7 June 2016, Ipswich Town beat AZ Alkmaar 3-0 in the first leg of the cup final and later defeated them 4-2 in the second leg, resulting in a 7-2 aggregate win and the trophy lift. Butcher was part of the winning team and participated in a charity cycling event to commemorate the victory, raising funds for Prostate Cancer UK and the Ipswich Town Academy.

Storms Desmond, Eva, Frank, and Gertrude caused significant flooding in Hawick, Jedburgh, Newcastleton, and Peebles. The full repair costs are yet to be determined, but the council will receive Bellwin Scheme support. They must contribute 0.2% of their net revenue budget (£508,000) and complete 240 repair projects, including 114 major tasks. Additional works may be needed for underwater bridge inspections.

Thomas Cook Airlines launches weekly Glasgow-Las Vegas flight next summer, following successful one-off trips in recent years. The Airbus A330 fleet will operate the route between 4 May and 31 October. CEO Christoph Debus says it's great news for holidaymakers, while Glasgow Airport's commercial director Francois Bourienne welcomes the new route, calling it excellent news for customers. Additionally, the airline announces three weekly Tunisia flights in 2015.

England, Italy, Czech Republic & Wales/Northern Ireland in potential groups for Euro 2016; seedings based on UEFA national team coefficient rankings; top seeds also include Spain, France, Germany, Portugal, Belgium; Bosnia, Ukraine, Sweden, Hungary as seeds in play-off draw; Republic of Ireland, Denmark, Norway, Slovenia possible opponents in play-off matches.

Damon Smith denied making an explosive device intending to endanger life, but at the Old Bailey he admitted to a bomb hoax. The prosecution claimed the device, containing ball bearings as shrapnel, was intended to explode and endanger lives on a Jubilee Line train. Smith, with Asperger's syndrome, had claimed the device was meant only to produce smoke but added the ball bearings to make it look more real. The device was found by passengers at London Bridge station and handed to a driver, who realised its significance.

Mansfield District Council debated the £250m Lindhurst scheme, facing 140 objections. It includes 1,700 homes, a new primary school, cemetery, community centre & park. Planning committee voted 5-5, with chairman casting vote in favour. Protesters shouted "shame". Largest ever submission by developers Lindhurst Group, promising 4,000 jobs. Objections include loss of countryside & habitat from Nottingham Wildlife Trust & Ramblers Association. Councillor Andrew Tristram raised concerns over congestion & ability to deliver benefits.
UN finds Europe throws away most fish globally, with 24% of catches discarded due to unplanned catches.

HP purchased Palm's WebOS operating system in 2011 for $1.2bn, but has not recovered its investment. LG acquired WebOS for its next-generation smart TV technology. WebOS was originally designed for Palm's smartphones and tablets, but has since been opened up for developers. The acquisition may help LG differentiate its devices through software-based innovation in user experience.

In a pre-season friendly, Ipswich Town and U player Joe Pigott equalised in the 89th minute, cancelling out Andre Dozzell's opener. Manager Mick McCarthy was furious with the goal, saying it was "garbage" and unforgiveable. He cited late goals in previous seasons as examples, and vowed to improve his team's performance in this regard.

Tests on Austen's glasses reveal her worsening eyesight due to possible arsenic poisoning from medications for her rheumatism. Library experts suggest this may have contributed to her early death at 41. Glasses' strength increased from +1.75 to +4.75/+5.0, making reading and writing difficult. Arsenic was commonly used in medications for other illnesses; Austen's glasses were preserved in her writing desk.

Archbishop Justin Welby announced plans to fix Easter Sunday date after meeting with Anglican Primates. 1928 Act of Parliament allows for change but has never been activated. Easter celebrates Jesus Christ's resurrection following crucifixion on Good Friday. Welby in talks with Pope Francis, Coptic leader, and Orthodox Patriarch to implement change in 5-10 years. Anglican source says 15 previous attempts to agree on common date. Easter date based on moon cycle and can be celebrated between 22 March and 25 April. Orthodox church has later Easter celebrations due to use of Julian calendar.

Monthly survey shows modest deterioration in business conditions, with output and new orders declining in April. Ulster Bank's chief economist, Richard Ramsey, says Northern Ireland's private sector activity decline compares to growth in other UK regions. Manufacturing continues to perform well, while retail sales and construction sectors see declines. Despite weak demand, companies continue to hire staff.

Opponents target high street shop in Penarth, Wales, since its opening in November. Party invites anarchist friends to throw eggs at posters of UKIP leader Nigel Farage and candidates John Rees-Evans. UKIP spokesperson states no eggs have been thrown since posters were put up.

On the opening night of One Man, Two Guvnors at Windsor's Theatre Royal, a flood halted the performance forcing audience members to be evacuated. The theatre director, Robert Miles, assured that the auditorium was dried out and the show would resume on Wednesday. The flood occurred after heavy rainfall, causing havoc in London as well. Wendy Sammes, one of the audience members, described the stormy atmosphere and its sudden impact on the theatre.

Fiji gained independence from Britain in 1970, and political upheaval has largely been driven by rivalry between the indigenous Fijian and ethnic Indian communities. In 2014, Frank Bainimarama became prime minister following a military coup in 2006. Fiji has a population of 876,0000 and an area of 18,376 sq km. Its major languages are English, Fijian, and Hindi, and its major religions are Christianity, Hinduism, and Islam. Life expectancy is 67 years for men and 72 years for women. The currency is the Fijian dollar, and the president is Jioji Konousi Konrote. Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama has championed equal rights for the Indian community and introduced stricter media control. Key dates in Fiji's history include Dutch explorer Abel Tasman's visit in 1643, independence in 1970, coups in 1987 and 1999, and the election of Frank Bainimarama as prime minister in 2014.

After a student, Ruby Rai, claimed political science was about cooking, her video went viral. This led to scrutiny of exam results, revealing low pass rates. The embarrassed state government took strict measures, but Ruby's interview footage cast doubt. The government suspended her and top science student Saurabh Shrestha's results, requiring them to take a written test and interview by subject experts on 3 June.

Since 15 April, approximately 30 people have lived in tents on St Peter's Square, outside the Central Library. Manchester City Council obtained a warrant to close the camp, which campaigners lost in an appeal. The demonstrators set up a new settlement half a mile away in St Anne's Square. Police and bailiffs broke up the St Peter's Square camp at 08:00 BST. Some protesters peacefully left, but others resisted. Campaigners sought to highlight temporary housing and homeless crises. The council said demonstrators behaved inappropriately in a public area. Deputy Leader Bernard Priest stated the camp had caused additional policing, security, and legal costs exceeding Â£88,000.

Two pieces of debris found separately by members of the public were flown to Australia for analysis. Darren Chester said the finds were consistent with drift modelling of how debris from the missing plane may have been carried by ocean currents. MH370 vanished in 2014 with 239 people on board en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing. The investigation team found both debris pieces were likely from a Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 aircraft, almost certainly from MH370. This suggests the search area in the southern Indian Ocean is correct. The search continues as 25,000 sq km must still be scanned.

RMT union plans further strike action against ScotRail's driver-only trains; Labour urges minister to intervene; Transport Scotland says minister has engaged with both sides; RMT opposes door control change; ScotRail argues safety benefits; Transport Scotland assures passengers 80% of services will run normally this weekend.

In the NBA playoffs, the Cavaliers trail 2-1 after losing their first two games. Kyrie Irving scored 30 points for Cleveland, while Steph Curry had 19 for the Warriors. Warriors coach Steve Kerr blamed his team's lack of preparation, and LeBron James credited his teammates for encouraging him to be more aggressive. Game 4 is scheduled for Friday in Cleveland.

The UK Singles Chart saw Sam Smith's Stay at Number One, selling 117,000 copies, beating Lady Gaga's Applause into second place. Miley Cyrus's We Can't Stop dropped to number three. Smith's previous highest charting single was his 2010 cover of Elton John's Your Song. Burn featured on the deluxe edition of Smith's album Halcyon, which climbed to 19 in the album chart. Smith said it meant the world to him to have a UK number one single. Arctic Monkeys' Why'd You Call Me When You're High entered the chart at eight, while The Wanted's We Own the Night reached 10th place. Ray Foxx's Boom Boom entered the charts at 12th. In the album chart, Britain's Got Talent duo Richard and Adam Johnson retained the top spot for a third consecutive week with their debut album, The Impossible Dream. The brothers' classical renditions album is now tied with Justin Timberlake's The 20/20 Experience for the most consecutive weeks at number one this year. Rudimental climbed to second place, while Imagine Dragons remained at three. White Lies entered the top five with Big TV, with Passenger's All The Little Lights completing the top five.

Council avoids £1.3m cuts through savings such as changing sickness absence policy and school energy incentives. Lib Dem proposal to cut senior councillor pay defeated; SNP opposed cuts to services for vulnerable people. Independent councillors propose cuts to funding for deprived areas, street cleansing, homeless support, women's aid groups, and Blas Music Festival. Savings required due to council tax freeze; Highland Council leader fears job cuts and service axing.

Reverend Barry Trayhorn, a Pentecostal Christian minister, was dismissed from his job as a gardening supervisor at HMP Littlehey after leading worship services where he read verses from the Bible regarding homosexuality. His case against the secretary of state for justice continues, alleging unfair dismissal.

Independent immigration inspector John Vine says Home Office must improve handling of 'overstayers', refusing them leave to remain in the UK. Failure could undermine public confidence, says Vine. Immigration Minister James Brokenshire acknowledges room for improvement. Report shows 'overstayers' in UK not increasing, numbers static. Capita, a private outsourcing group, contracted by Home Office to review migrant records; however, Vine finds significant inaccuracies in Capita's work.

Dolgellau's My Dentist practice will close on 31 March due to recruitment difficulties. Deputy mayor Delwyn Evans blames lack of dentists in rural areas. My Dentist clinical director Steve Williams says there is a shortage of dentists in rural Wales. Betsi Cadwaladr Health Board intends to re-commission dental services in the area. Welsh Government spokesman says associated funding remains with the health board to re-commission the service.

A search for missing climber Liam Day, 26, was conducted by police and coastguard crews before being suspended. His partner, Emily Brown, posted on Facebook suggesting he may not be found. Mr Day is thought to have been climbing near Durlston Country Park. Anyone with information is asked to contact police.

In the All-Ireland semi-final, McGuinness must develop a strategy to counter the champion's attacking style. Trusting his players, he focuses on their abilities rather than outside expectations. His approach is consistent; it's about football, not odds or rankings.

High Fliers report reveals 1,000 graduates rejected job offers in 2015, leaving employers scrambling for replacements. Around 20,000 students were recruited mainly during their final year, giving them time to reconsider options. Top employers compete for best candidates, offering up to six job offers. 2016 recruitment at highest level, with graduate salaries staying at around Â£30,000.

British Transport Police report that a man suffered head and leg injuries after falling onto the tracks at a London station shortly after England's World Cup win. The man is not thought to be critically ill; London Ambulance treated him and took him to St George's Hospital. The station was evacuated while the man was treated, and South West Trains services were temporarily suspended. Officers are investigating the circumstances of the incident.

Malta, located south of Sicily, has a rich history of colonial control by various nations including Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, Arabs, and France and Britain. Independence was achieved in 1964, and Malta's strategic position has made it an important trading post. Tourism is the main source of income, and Malta is a popular holiday destination. The President is Marie-Louise Coleiro Preca, who was elected in 2014 and has been active in national politics for forty years. Prime Minister Joseph Muscat leads the Labour Party, which has been in government since 2013. Malta's history includes significant dates such as 1814 when it became a crown colony of the British Empire, and 1964 when it gained independence.

34-year-old actor plays grieving investment banker in Jean-Marc Vallee's tragicomedy Demolition, making its world premiere at TIFF. Vallee praises Gyllenhaal's performance, calling the film "probably the most rock 'n' roll film I've ever made". Other world premieres include Michael Moore's satirical US military film Where to Invade Next. TIFF traditionally kicks off awards season, with past winners including 12 Years a Slave, The King's Speech, Slumdog Millionaire, and American Beauty. Last year's winner was The Imitation Game.

Belfast Telegraph covers exclusive story of young boy injured in petrol bomb attack battling brain condition; mother speaks out about son's injuries. Irish News reports on controversial Stormont scheme granting funds to Orange Halls, criticized as biased towards loyalist organizations. Also covers 11-year-old boy with life-threatening epilepsy recovering in US after cannabis oil treatment, and protests against Trump's travel ban.

A survey of 1,000 adults found that many are unaware of the risks of excessive music listening, which can cause tinnitus. Action on Hearing Loss warns that one in 10 people in the UK experiences tinnitus daily, affecting concentration and sleep. The group has launched an audio demonstration of tinnitus to raise awareness and urges people to take precautions when listening to music. DJ Paul Oakenfold supports the campaign, urging fans to use ear defenders and keep volumes safe.
France wins mixed team event at Hopman Cup; Gasquet beats Sock, Vandeweghe stuns Mladenovic in singles matches before winning doubles decider.

Australia's Jones feels the longstanding rivalry between England and Ireland as they face off at Twickenham on Saturday. Jones, who succeeded Eddie Jones, says he's committed to the team despite being Australian. He sees Manu Tuilagi as a 12 for England and praises his passing ability. England are tied with France at the top of the Six Nations table after two games. Jones insists the team is a work in progress but praises player commitment and independence. He expects Ireland to employ their traditional kicking game.

In the six months to September, Scottish paramedics treated around 12,000 people for alcohol-related illnesses. The figures were obtained by the Scottish Conservatives through freedom of information laws. Alcohol significantly impacted the ambulance service's operations. NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde had the highest number of alcohol-related 999 call-outs at 3,849, followed by NHS Lothian (1,935) and NHS Lanarkshire (1,470). Tory health spokesman Jackson Carlaw called the situation "deep-rooted and complex," adding that the Scottish government and NHS could do more to discourage reckless drinking and provide support for paramedics. Public Health Minister Maureen Watt stated that Scotland was leading the way in tackling alcohol misuse, but excessive drinking still put pressure on services.

Economic inactivity in Northern Ireland stands at 27%, including students, health-affected, carers, and parents. The 'Enabling Success' strategy targets those with work-limiting health issues, lone parents, and carers for job support. Minister Farry acknowledges severe health limitations but stresses potential for supported participation. Enterprise Minister Arlene Foster highlights need to address inactivity to boost NI economy. By 2030, strategy aims for employment levels above UK average.

Billionaire and reality TV star Trump criticised McCain's hero status due to his time as a POW, prompting widespread criticism. Trump later clarified his remarks, saying captivity didn't diminish hero status but disagreed with McCain's Senate performance. Trump has clashed with McCain in the past; McCain accused Trump of inflaming anti-immigrant sentiment.

Canadian author Tim Winton dies at age 70; his agent confirms assisted death, legal in Canada since early 2021. He published over 30 works including poetry, fiction, and non-fiction, winning Order of Canada award. Most famous for baseball-themed fantasy novel Shoeless Joe, later made into film Field of Dreams, starring Kevin Costner. After head injury, Winton lost interest in fiction, but resumed writing; final work Russian Dolls due out next year.

Máiría Cahill, Labour Party candidate, won a by-election to fill a vacant seat after Jimmy Harte's resignation. She previously accused an IRA man of raping her at 16, resulting in his prosecution and acquittal. This year, NI's PPS apologised for handling her allegations, and she now plans to advocate for abuse victims in the Senate.

Separate calls from boys led ChildLine to launch a campaign against porn addiction among 12- to 13-year-olds. One boy feared he was losing his chance at marriage due to porn-induced perceptions of girls. A UK-wide poll found that one in five children had seen shocking pornographic images. Des Mannion says society must address the issue to protect affected young people.

Mariner Street car park near the train station will be demolished and replaced with a 725-bedroom student block featuring a nightclub, gym, offices, bars, restaurants, and shops. The 22-story tower will be the second tallest building in Swansea, after Meridian Quay. Construction begins this year and is expected to be completed by 2018. The project will help meet the growing demand for student housing in Swansea as the city's universities expand. Swansea council leader Rob Stewart believes the project will be a major step forward for the city's regeneration.

Floods submerge parts of Queensland and NSW as Cyclone Debbie's remnants bring torrential rain. Towns affected include Billinudgel, where residents used surfboards to navigate flooded streets. Brisbane and Beaudesert are evacuated, while other towns suffer road washouts and power outages. Authorities warn of a bull shark in the floods. Storm system moves out to sea, bringing relief to NSW and Queensland.

iPad software glitch halted American Airlines flights, forcing pilots to rely on printed maps. Paperless cockpits aimed at reducing weight and saving fuel costs. Investigation ongoing; carriers like United, Delta, British Airways, and Ryanair also use electronic flight bag systems.

On Wednesday, 35-year-old Girish Pote was convicted by a Thane court for the 2013 murder of his wife Madhuvanti Pathak. He chopped her body into pieces before confessing to relatives and police. A life term in India typically lasts 14 years, but Judge Mridula Bhatia ruled that Pote would remain in prison for life due to the gruesome nature of the crime. Pathak held a French passport as her mother was from France. The couple married in 2006 and had a two-year-old son at the time of the crime. Police said the fight was over money and Pathak's desire to return to France.

Bradford Council plans a one-way gyratory along East Parade, Hanover Street, and Cavendish Street to address traffic congestion. Deputy leader Val Salter stresses urgency, with display of plans at Airedale Shopping Centre from 11-13 June.

23-year-old Thorpe has appeared seven times for Bradford this season, last playing in a 5-2 loss to Ipswich on 7 November. The former Man Utd trainee could make his debut against Millwall on Saturday. Currently 7th in League One, Bradford is out of the play-offs on goal difference.

A radio presenter tricked Spanish PM Mariano Rajoy into thinking he was speaking with fake Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont, who wanted to discuss Catalonia's secession. Rajoy, whose party won most seats but lacked a majority, was eager to meet. However, the prankster revealed himself, leaving Rajoy disappointed but grateful for their good humor. This incident follows similar prank calls received by high-profile figures like former UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and Cuban leader Fidel Castro.

Lib Dem Baroness Hamwee questioned whether the £1 pay rate for non-criminal detainees was something society could be proud of. Baroness Williams of Trafford explained that inmate work was voluntary, helping meet recreational and intellectual needs. Labour's Lord Rosser claimed hundreds of detainees were paid over £45,000 for work. Baroness Williams insisted the benefit was to the detainees, but Lady Boothroyd pressed for clarification on who reaped the financial benefit.

This year's Borders Book Festival will announce the winner of the Â£25,000 Walter Scott Prize, which has been awarded to Jo Baker, Sebastian Barry, Charlotte Hobson, Hannah Kent, Francis Spufford, Graham Swift, and Rose Tremain. Judges extended the shortlist to seven titles due to the variety of the longlist, which offers readers joy in discovering unusual subjects and times, as well as appreciation of historical research and a visceral connection with characters. The winners will be announced on 17 June.

In the 2nd Test between Bangladesh and England, the hosts needed 33 runs to seal their first Test win, with only 2 wickets remaining. Broad (2-26) took 2 wickets, and Bangladesh chased a victory target of 286. Broad said it had been a "fantastic game", adding that Bangladesh had shown "huge skill". The opening Test of the 2-match series had already set a world record for reviews with 24.

Members of UCU Scotland voted for strike action over job security at the university's medical school. The university expressed disappointment with the decision. UCU raised concerns about potential discrimination in the process. The university spokesperson stated that no compulsory redundancies would be needed due to alternative employment offers.

Jay Brenton Liptrot, 43, owner of the property where 5 people died in a 2012 fire, did not enter a plea at his first court appearance. The victims included Lee-Ann Shiers, 20, her partner Liam Timbrell, 23, their 15-month-old son Charlie, and Ms Shiers' four-year-old nephew and two-year-old niece. Melanie Smith, who started the fire in a row over a shared hallway, was jailed for 30 years for the five counts of murder. Mr Liptrot will appear at Mold Crown Court in May.

Aberdeen Sea Cadets base at Pocra Quay witnessed a disgraceful incident involving a 34-year-old man. Police Scotland described the event as deplorable. The suspect is expected to appear in court but has been released pending further investigations.

Children falling behind in reading can face lifelong consequences, impacting their educational and career prospects. A coalition of organizations including Save the Children and the Scottish Book Trust aims to get all 11-year-olds reading well within a generation. They advocate daily parent-read sessions and recommend 10 minutes per day. However, many low-income families lack access to children's books, and fathers from these households are less likely to read to their children. This affects children's literacy, with those read to as toddlers more likely to become keen readers. The coalition expects the number of children living in poverty to rise to 220,000 in Scotland. With the rise of digital media, children are increasingly reading texts and webpages instead of books.

In 2016, 30-year-old Martinelli joined the Giants, committing to the franchise alongside Mark Garside, 28, who spent four years with the Edinburgh Capitals. Both players are excited to spend another season in Belfast chasing trophies. Head Coach Adam Keefe believes Martinelli is a great guy to have around the locker room and is excited about Garside's extension. Garside was part of the Giants squad that won two league championships and the recent World Championship gold.
Teenager Rasmus Barlow, 16, reported missing; police conduct large-scale search. Death not considered suspicious; file being prepared for coroner. Family supported by liaison officers.

Regina Hungerford, 55, was found by the Education Workforce Council to have likely made contact with a 17-year-old pupil during an altercation in her classroom. Despite her denial, the panel ruled her conduct unacceptable and will decide whether to strike her off the register at a later date.

In celebration of Star Wars Day (May 4), big brands like Heathrow Airport, Mark Hamill, and Darth Vader use hashtags like #MayThe4thBeWithYou to engage fans. Charities also join in, raising awareness for their causes. Global brands sell products, and celebrities like Theo Paphitis participate.

Retired generals and admirals endorse Trump as 'commander-in-chief', despite controversy surrounding Trump University investigation. Trump dismisses allegations of improper donation to Florida official, while Clinton releases campaign ad featuring veterans criticising Trump.
21-year-old footballer joins Colchester on one-year deal after brief stint with QPR. He made 7 league appearances since joining from Championship side.

In October, Phillip Pullman's new trilogy "The Book of Dust" begins with its first novel; title TBA. First book in His Dark Materials series (Northern Lights, 1995) sold over 17.5 million copies in 40 languages. Story follows Lyra Belacqua from infancy to adulthood. Watch Pullman discuss the new series in a video.

A Red Cross pool safety poster sparked controversy for depicting black children as "not cool" while white children were considered "cool". This led to an apology from the Red Cross and removal of the poster from their website.

Winkelman confirms Karl Robinson as manager for next season despite previous uncertainty. Robinson, who led the club to promotion from League One, was criticised for misuse of funds but Winkelman trusts him and believes they can handle the increased pressure as a bigger club in League One.
Scottish actors James Cosmo (Braveheart) and Karen Gillan (Dr Who) join EIFF as honorary patrons; Gillan also makes her directing debut.

Spurs' left-back Rose criticised the club for not signing well-known players, leading to controversy. Rose apologised for his comments, and manager Pochettino stated that Rose still has a future at the club. Tottenham, who finished second in the Premier League last season, have not signed any players yet. Rose will miss the game against Newcastle due to a knee problem, but right-back Trippier's ankle injury is not as severe as first feared.

International Ski Federation (FIS) bans Thai skier Mae and five officials for manipulating results to ensure her Sochi Olympics qualification. FIS imposes punishment after investigating Slovenian races held before January qualification deadline. Mae, born in Singapore and competing under her father's surname Vanakorn, finished 67th in Giant Slalom at Sochi Olympics. Court of Arbitration for Sport to consider appeal.

In the seventh minute, Rhys Browne scored for Macclesfield Town in a 1-0 win over Eastleigh. Both sides created chances in an open game, with Macclesfield leading at half-time. Despite another goal disallowed, Eastleigh came close to equalising before Macclesfield substitutes extended their lead in the second half. Final score: Eastleigh 0, Macclesfield Town 1.

Warner Bros TV is yet to reach salary agreements with the Big Bang Theory cast of Jim Parsons, Johnny Galecki, Kaley Cuoco, Simon Helberg, and Kunal Nayyar, potentially delaying production. The cast are still expected to return to work, as the popular CBS sitcom was recently extended for three more series until 2017. If new deals are not reached within the next two weeks, the actors could become the highest-paid TV actors in the US, surpassing Ashton Kutcher and Jon Cryer from Two and a Half Men.

Surrey man Matthew Cobden appeared in court following fatal crash involving Alexander Worth near North Warnborough. Cobden gave limited testimony before court referred case to Winchester Crown Court. District Judge Philip Gillibrand offered condolences to Worth's family.

Refugees call for action; Welsh council welcomes UK plan to resettle 20,000 Syrians; demonstrations in Swansea & Caernarfon; minister calls refugee crisis 'most serious human-made disaster'; David Cameron announces UK to accept 20,000 Syrian refugees; Wales summit next week; local authorities seek support for costs.

Jhon Jairo Velasquez, known as Popeye, was a notorious Colombian hitman for drug baron Pablo Escobar. He confessed to 300 killings and claimed responsibility for up to 3,000 murders between the 1980s and 1990s. However, he also provided evidence against an ex-justice minister convicted of ordering a rival's killing. After serving two decades in prison, Velasquez was released on probation in 2021. Colombians are divided over his early release, with some victims insisting he has not paid for his crimes, while others argue it is time for a second chance.

Kurt Gidley, 34, became the first rugby league player to wear a camera during a match, offering a unique perspective on the sport. However, the device was removed due to technical issues. Coach Tony Smith said Gidley was focused on playing football and felt the camera may have affected his performance. Despite their poor performance, Smith believes the technology could still provide valuable footage and hopes Sky Sports will continue experimenting with it.

Police investigated a sexual assault at Auchinlee care home in Campbeltown; the suspect is an 82-year-old man. The Care Inspectorate is monitoring the situation and encourages people with concerns to report them via their helpline.

Des McDaid, who bravely revealed his identity, testified about the abuse he suffered at the Clontarf orphanage in Perth, Australia. He was sent there from St Joseph's Home in Derry, Northern Ireland, at age eight. Mr McDaid experienced brutal treatment and sexual abuse by Christian Brothers and a lay teacher. He also revealed rapes by an older boy at St Joseph's Home and further abuse in Australia. At age 48, Mr McDaid traced his mother, who had given him up for adoption. They are now in regular contact, and he plans to visit her next month. The HIA inquiry is investigating child abuse in NI religious and state-run institutions.
21-year-old British player Edmund lost to Wawrinka in 3 sets; Canadian Raonic advanced to semis after beating Nadal; Bedene knocked out in India.

Irish rock band U2's 50-year-old musician received treatment in Munich and will recuperate in Ireland. Their US tour on 3 June and Glastonbury appearance are postponed; further info on other tour dates to be announced. Manager Paul McGuinness says they'll reinstate tour dates & resume rehearsals as soon as possible. Fans advised to monitor U2 website for updates.

A plane crash occurred around 3:25 PM BST between Abergavenny and Raglan, resulting in three casualties including passengers and pilot. Road closed; 120 liters of fuel contained. South Wales fire engines on site.

Angela Scott, 42, starts as Aberdeen City Council's new CEO in July, succeeding Valerie Watts. She joins from the council's director of corporate governance, where she excelled. Her salary is Â£144,685. Mrs Scott aims to work with colleagues, elected members, and key partners to deliver Aberdeen's priorities.

United defender Matteo Darmian suffers a dislocated shoulder, ruling him out for several weeks. Coach Louis van Gaal says the team has no fit full-backs available due to injuries, leaving young players Cameron Borthwick-Jackson and Donald Love as their only options.

33-year-old Kenneth Harper was convicted of sex crimes, assault, and reckless behavior, and sentenced to three years for the remaining offenses. His rape convictions were overturned due to defense arguments about mutual corroboration. The court found that the time gap between the incidents and lack of compelling similarities made it impossible to link them.

Actor, Tom Broadbent, is excited to portray Tommy Butler in "The Great Train Robbery: A Copper's Tale," airing later this year. This follows the previously aired "A Robber's Tale," starring Luke Evans as Bruce Reynolds. Chris Chibnall, the show's executive producer and writer, calls Broadbent a "dream piece of casting" due to his past awards and roles. Butler, nicknamed the "Grey Fox," investigated the Great Train Robbery, leading to the arrest and long prison sentences of several robbers. He died at 57 in 1970.

Lithuanian schoolgirl beaten in Peterborough's Central Park; mother posts footage on Facebook seeking information; police investigating; victim says attackers thought she was cheeky; brawl involved 20-25 girls; footage shows victim being kicked.

The Maccabees achieve their first number one album with "Marks To Prove It", narrowly beating Lianne La Havas' "Blood". Indie band The Maccabees break streaming records in the UK with 2.03m plays in their first week. Cilla Black's posthumous entry into the album chart sees her highest-ever chart position at 14 and her 1963 number one single "Anyone Who Had A Heart" enters the singles chart at 41 after 51 years. Drag Me Down marks One Direction's return as a foursome following Zayn Malik's departure. Calvin Harris and Disciples' "How Deep Is Your Love" climbs to number two, while Little Mix's "Black Magic" falls to number three.

One Direction continues as a four-piece after Zayn Malik's departure due to stress and rumours of a breakup. Liam Payne thanked fans for their support and the band has continued its On the Road Again tour. They will play Cardiff's Millennium Stadium on 5 and 6 June.
Police Scotland investigate leaked information about witness names and alleged gun attack on social media.

Steven Flynn broke into St Johnstone's stadium with a crowbar to pay off drug debts. Police were alerted at 2:40 am but mistakenly thought it was an alarm accident. A cleaner discovered the break-in hours later and found a muddy crowbar under the reception desk. Flynn was jailed for 16 months for the offense.

UKIP leader Nigel Farage visited Sleaford to support his party's candidate in the upcoming by-election. He stood in front of a UKIP poster displaying the incorrect spelling of the constituency name, "Hykenham," which drew laughter and criticism on social media. The actual constituency name is "North Hykeham."

In the first half, Blair Henderson scored for the hosts after 24 seconds following a cross from Michael McKenna. Stirling had a chance but Moses Olanrewaju's shot was saved. Brian Martin was sent off, but Stirling couldn't equalize despite Sean Dickson missing a penalty.

Fiona Barnes, who faked terminal cancer, was sentenced to 15 months in jail for theft from Preston's Space Centre and perverting the course of justice. She was ordered to repay £1 despite having no money. The centre described the ruling as outrageous and an insult. Barnes stole £24,713 in 2012 and attempted to cover her tracks by falsifying grant documents. The Space Centre was eventually saved by a charitable company.

Experienced 31-year-old defender Adam El-Abd joins Shrewsbury Town from Bristol City after starting his career at Brighton, amassing over 300 appearances in 11 years. He previously had loan spells with Bury, Swindon, and Gillingham. El-Abd joins fellow defender Joe Riley in Micky Mellon's squad as they prepare for the new League One campaign.

England rugby coach Jones aims for World Cup success, citing need for more leaders; coaches work on developing potential leaders within team. Captain Dylan Hartley to lead Six Nations squad, with Owen Farrell as possible replacement.

Somerset signs experienced Australian batsman Rogers (38) for County Championship season. Maynard describes the signing as "top", "marquee", and "great". Rogers will bat at number three, replacing Abell who bats at four. Maynard hopes Rogers' experience will benefit the team and support Trescothick and Abell.

A Range Rover crashed into a house on Hearthcote Road in Swadlincote, Derbyshire, around 2 AM BST, causing structural damage and forcing two residents to evacuate. Although no one was injured, police are investigating the incident and seeking witnesses. The road was closed for approximately an hour, and one driver sustained minor injuries but did not require hospitalization.

Demolition of Kingsway building, begun in 2015, took longer than expected due to additional asbestos. The council purchased the site for transformation into a business district. Internal works complete; exterior demolition ongoing, scheduled for completion in spring.

Rovers led 2-1 until Hanley's goal was initially disallowed due to O'Hara's clearance. Manager Gary Bowyer urged the Football League to adopt goal-line technology, as Fulham's Kit Symons acknowledged the disputed goal could have been legitimate.

19-year-old Polish international joins Premier League champions Leicester City for £7.5m, signing a 5-year deal. He impressed at Euro 2016 and will make his debut against Barcelona in a friendly before the new season starts. This is Claudio Ranieri's fifth summer signing after Zieler, Hernandez, Mendy, and Musa.

The Burrell Collection closes this Sunday and reopens in 2020 following a major renovation costing up to £66m. The museum, located in Pollok Country Park, will feature new roof and energy-efficient glazing, two additional floors of exhibition space, allowing 90% of the 8,000-piece collection to be displayed. During renovations, select pieces will be displayed at Kelvingrove Museum and Art Gallery.

Finance Minister Máirtín Ó Muilleoir raised fresh concerns over the heating subsidy scheme for poultry farmers, which involved replacing LPG systems with wood chip boilers. Moy Park, a poultry processing company, met with officials to address concerns about the scheme's budgetary impact. The company stated its commitment to responsible heat use and benchmarked energy usage in the poultry industry. Minister Ó Muilleoir described proposed cost control measures as a "sticking plaster" and expressed his opposition to a "botched solution" to the RHI scandal.
Body of unknown man found in Belsyde Avenue field; police investigating identity for further inquiry into cause of death.
